message.content:
A merism, in the context of rhetoric and figurative language, refers to an expression or figure of speech in which a part of something stands for the whole, or vice versa. It is a type of metonymy, where one thing is used as a representative of another. 

For example, if I were to say "The White House issued a statement," I am using a merism because I have referred to the U.S. government as "the White House" -- a part standing for the whole. Another example could be saying "The Kremlin commented on the situation," when referring to the Russian government.

Merisms can be found in everyday language and are common rhetorical devices used for simplicity, clarity, or emphasis.
